issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual instructions) requires Farm to maintain its animals as a List and to initialize the collection as an ArrayList in the no-arg constructor. The solution implementation instead uses a Set (HashSet) for the animals collection and exposes getter/setter returning a Set. This is a structural mismatch: tests or student expectations that rely on insertion order (ArrayList) or on the declared types (List/ArrayList) will be broken or produce nondeterministic behavior when using a Set. The template's Farm.java TODO and the problem description explicitly ask for a List/ArrayList, so the solution's use of Set is inconsistent with the specified design and can confuse students and break order-dependent tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's Farm use the collection type specified in the problem: declare the animals field as List<Animal> and initialize it as new ArrayList<>() in the no-arg constructor; update the getter and setter signatures to return/accept List<Animal> and adjust imports accordingly. This preserves insertion order and matches the UML/textual instructions in the problem statement (alternatively, if Set is intended, update the problem statement and template to explicitly require Set/HashSet).

issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires the Farm to hold its animals in a List implemented using an ArrayList and to provide a getter/setter for that List. The solution implementation instead declares the collection as a Set<Animal> and uses HashSet internally (imports and signatures use Set/HashSet). This is a semantic mismatch of the same conceptual entity (the Farm's animal collection): students are told to use a List/ArrayList but the reference solution uses Set/HashSet. This difference can confuse students when they try to follow the instructions (initializing an ArrayList, using List-specific types/expectations) and when comparing their code to the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem statement: change the Farm's collection type to List<Animal>, import java.util.ArrayList and java.util.List, initialize animals = new ArrayList<>(); and update the getter/setter signatures to return/accept List<Animal>. This makes the template, instructions, and solution consistent and removes unnecessary cognitive load.
